quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I was mentoring Brian, but he was also my boss. I was 52, the average age was 26. I had to be both wise and curious, and often the dumbest person in the room.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A practical mindset for thriving as a senior/older leader in a young, fast-moving org: pair wisdom with curiosity and embrace not knowing.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Brian assumed everybody else was going to work at the same pace and duration. His point of view is like, "Hey, we're having a meeting in the office tonight at 10 o'clock. Be there."
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A concrete example of “founder mode” expectations that practitioners can anticipate and proactively manage (pace, boundaries, operating norms).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When you have older brains connecting the dots, younger team members being really fast and focused, it's brilliant, and people won't notice your wrinkles as much as they'll notice your energy.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A team-composition model: combine pattern-recognition and synthesis with speed and execution for outsized results.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you think about the caterpillar to butterfly journey, midlife is the chrysalis. Midlife is not crisis.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A reframing mental model that turns a commonly feared career/life stage into a deliberate transformation phase.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One of the most common things I hear from PMs and founders that I talk to is, "I know I should be speaking to customers more, but I just don't have the time or the tools."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures a common practitioner bottleneck—customer research is known to be important but blocked by time/tooling constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Great Question makes it easy for anyone on your team, not just researchers, to recruit participants, run interviews, send surveys, test prototypes, and then share it all with powerful video clips.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Promotes a scalable operating model where customer insight work is democratized beyond dedicated researchers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's everything you need to put your customers at the center of your product decisions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concise decision-making principle: anchor product choices in direct customer evidence.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With a prompt as simple as, "Why did users choose us over competitors?"
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, reusable research question teams can apply to uncover differentiation and positioning insights.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now, you can assess risk, secure the trust of your customers, and automate compliance for SOC 2, ISO 27,001, HIPAA, and more with a single platform, Vanta.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights an operational approach—centralize and automate compliance to reduce overhead while building customer trust.

quotes.topic_title: Setting up the three career arcs
quotes.text: I'm thinking that the way that we break up this conversation is kind of break it up into three parts, which are kind of the three arcs of your career.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A simple, reusable framework for structuring a career narrative (or interview) into distinct arcs.

quotes.topic_title: Setting up the three career arcs
quotes.text: The three parts are your early career, building Joie de Vivre, your time at Airbnb, where we got to work together, and then talking through what you're working on now, the Modern Elder Academy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of the “three arcs” model applied to a real career, useful as a template for others.

quotes.topic_title: Setting up the three career arcs
quotes.text: Let's paint a picture of just what it was like for you to join Airbnb in your fifties surrounded by a bunch of 20 something, 30 somethings reporting to Brian Chesky, who is, I don't know, in his thirties.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive setup—joining a high-growth startup later in life—which tees up lessons about age, leadership, and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Joining Airbnb at 52: culture shock
quotes.text: I had to be both wise and curious, and often the dumbest person in the room.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A practical mindset for operating effectively in a new domain: combine experience with beginner’s curiosity and comfort with not knowing.

quotes.topic_title: Joining Airbnb at 52: culture shock
quotes.text: It required me to have a certain amount of humility as well as to be reporting to a guy 21 years younger than me, Brian.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Highlights humility as an operational requirement (not a virtue signal) when navigating status/age inversions in fast-growing companies.

quotes.topic_title: Joining Airbnb at 52: culture shock
quotes.text: At some point, I just said, "Listen, let's get some older people who are hosts in here to see how well they will be versed in managing their listing purely on mobile."
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A concrete research tactic: bring the actual user segment into the room to pressure-test product assumptions (here, “mobile-only”).

quotes.topic_title: Joining Airbnb at 52: culture shock
quotes.text: There were times where I was a voice for older users, in this case, hosts, that was helpful to guys and women in their twenties who were the engineers and designers and product managers.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Shows how diversity of age/experience can function as a product advantage by representing underserved user perspectives.

quotes.topic_title: Joining Airbnb at 52: culture shock
quotes.text: I think the key for me to work in that environment and make it work was to not pretend to know things I didn't know, it was to have a sense of humor and humility in how I operated, and it was to show respect and hope that I got it in return.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: An actionable operating playbook for cross-functional trust: admit gaps, use humor, lead with humility, and model respect.

quotes.topic_title: Working for Brian Chesky in founder mode
quotes.text: Brian would go to experts and say to the expert, "I don't know what the hell I'm doing."
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Models a practical learning tactic for founders/PMs: explicitly admit gaps and seek domain experts to accelerate competence.

quotes.topic_title: Working for Brian Chesky in founder mode
quotes.text: What was hard with Brian is, I'd say, three things. Number one is Brian assumed everybody else was going to work at the same pace and duration, and he still has this issue.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A useful diagnostic framework for working with intense founders: identify specific recurring failure modes (starting with pace/expectations).

quotes.topic_title: Working for Brian Chesky in founder mode
quotes.text: "Hey, we're having a meeting in the office tonight at 10 o'clock, be there."
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A concrete example of founder-mode expectation-setting that practitioners can anticipate, negotiate, or design guardrails around.

quotes.topic_title: Working for Brian Chesky in founder mode
quotes.text: To come into a room and sort of see something, and then point out the things that are wrong makes you feel good. If you don't have emotional intelligence, that process can really piss people off or demotivate people.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Highlights a counterproductive leadership pattern in reviews and why emotional intelligence is a key lever for maintaining team motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Working for Brian Chesky in founder mode
quotes.text: I'd say the third thing for Brian was the sense that adding a zero to something in terms of expectations, or thinking you're going to set a deadline that is unreasonable is necessary.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Captures a common founder-mode goal-setting tactic ("add a zero") that teams can recognize and manage to reduce stress and misalignment.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics for succeeding with intense founders
quotes.text: You start with that, because that actually helps to make sure there's alignment. Frankly, if there's not alignment, you might as well not have the meeting. Let's spend the rest of this meeting talking about alignment.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A strong meeting tactic: explicitly prioritize alignment first, and treat misalignment as the only agenda until resolved.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics for succeeding with intense founders
quotes.text: "Brian, let's talk about what we're trying to accomplish here. Let's get really clear," and you probably did this, but, "let's get really clear on what both, what's the intention of this iteration that we're doing on the product? What defines success, and what do I want to get accomplished in this meeting?"
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A practical opening script for founder-heavy meetings that forces clarity on intent, success criteria, and meeting outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics for succeeding with intense founders
quotes.text: That's what I would do, because that's something you can come back to over and over again during the rest of the meeting when Brian or the founder, whomever it is, is beating you up on something, saying like, "Well, let me tell you why it looks like that or why we're doing that." It goes back to that, the three principles or the three key goals we're trying to do with this product update.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A reusable “anchor” technique: define a small set of goals upfront and use them to steer nonlinear, high-pressure discussions back on track.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics for succeeding with intense founders
quotes.text: Yeah, I think the other thing is PowerPoint or whatever tool you're using, just be careful about being overly reliant upon it, especially when you have a combustible founder who may take you off path, such that your deck in its current order makes no sense at all.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Counterintuitive presentation advice: minimize dependence on linear decks because intense founders can rapidly change the meeting flow.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics for succeeding with intense founders
quotes.text: I always wanted to really limit the deck as much as possible, because I didn't know where the meeting was going to go. I wanted the decks helpful at the start, at the very start, to just set principles, set goals.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for founder meetings: keep decks minimal and use them primarily to establish principles and goals, not to drive the whole conversation.

quotes.topic_title: Intergenerational collaboration and modern elder value
quotes.text: As you get older, the brain shrinks a little bit and you have crystallized intelligence. In crystallized intelligence, what's going on is you're going from left brain to right brain more adeptly. There's a little bit less focus, a little more holistic thinking, systemic thinking, connecting the dots.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Introduces a useful mental model (fluid vs. crystallized intelligence) for designing mixed-age teams that balance speed with systems thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Intergenerational collaboration and modern elder value
quotes.text: Part of my job sometimes was to find the blind spot.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A practical role definition for senior/experienced teammates: proactively surface risks and second-order effects others may miss.

quotes.topic_title: Intergenerational collaboration and modern elder value
quotes.text: If we're as big as we're going to be three years from now, I promise you we're going to be regulated. I promise you we're going to be paying occupancy taxes. Let's take some proactive steps toward building a strategy for how we're going to be regulated.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Concrete example of anticipating inevitable external constraints (regulation/taxes) early and building strategy before it becomes a crisis.

quotes.topic_title: Intergenerational collaboration and modern elder value
quotes.text: I call this invisible productivity. It's productivity in which you make everybody else around you better.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Memorable framing for management impact: value isn’t just individual output, but amplifying the performance of others.

quotes.topic_title: Intergenerational collaboration and modern elder value
quotes.text: No, in my part of France, a confidant is somebody who gives you confidence.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Reframes mentorship as confidence-building through questions and support—an actionable approach for leaders working with younger teammates.

quotes.topic_title: Ageism in tech and adapting work arrangements
quotes.text: In Airbnb, we had a group called Wisdom at Airbnb. It was an employee resource group for people 40 and older.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Concrete example of an ERG structure that gives older employees a collective voice and visibility inside a tech company.

quotes.topic_title: Ageism in tech and adapting work arrangements
quotes.text: Ultimately, we had these senior nomads come in and be like the voice of the customer for 10 weeks at Airbnb.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Actionable program idea: bring in older users as a time-boxed “voice of customer” mechanism to improve product empathy and decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Ageism in tech and adapting work arrangements
quotes.text: The question, I think, will be if what AI cannot do is the human wisdom piece, artificial intelligence and human wisdom might be the balance beams here.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for workforce strategy: pair AI capabilities with uniquely human strengths like judgment and wisdom.

quotes.topic_title: Ageism in tech and adapting work arrangements
quotes.text: I took a substantial pay cut. I think it went down to 40% or 50% time, and my stock, my options were dropped to that level, my salaries dropped to that level, because I didn't want to work full time anymore.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Practical career/work-arrangement tactic: negotiate reduced time and compensation to keep contributing while avoiding full-time load.

quotes.topic_title: Ageism in tech and adapting work arrangements
quotes.text: Long story short is I just think that older people might look at their workload and say, "I'm willing to take a 20% or a 40% pay cut to go to 80% or 60% time," and the company is going to get their money's worth in that.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Counterintuitive retention lever for companies and individuals: part-time senior talent can be high-ROI due to accumulated organizational know-how.

quotes.topic_title: How to thrive in tech as you age
quotes.text: Show up with curiosity and a passionate engagement for what you do, and people won't necessarily notice your wrinkles as much as they'll notice your energy.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Practical guidance for midlife professionals: lead with curiosity and visible engagement so perceived value outweighs age signals.

quotes.topic_title: How to thrive in tech as you age
quotes.text: Energy has two parts to it.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A simple framework that breaks “energy” into components you can deliberately cultivate.

quotes.topic_title: How to thrive in tech as you age
quotes.text: We talk about gender fluidity. Well, there could be age fluidity. They're not defined by their age.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes career longevity around presence and behavior rather than chronology.

quotes.topic_title: How to thrive in tech as you age
quotes.text: I was very approachable.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Highlights approachability as a concrete, underappreciated career lever for staying influential and relevant.

quotes.topic_title: How to thrive in tech as you age
quotes.text: I just think show up with that passionate engagement, that curiosity, that energy, the ability to be both the learner and the teacher, with respect for people that are younger than you, and you're going to probably do pretty well.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A compact checklist of behaviors that compound into sustained career success in tech as you age.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Imagine starting a project at work, and your vision is clear, you know exactly who's doing what and where to find the data that you need to do your part.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical north-star description of what “good” project setup looks like: clarity on ownership and information access.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In fact, you don't have to waste time searching for anything because everything your team needs from project trackers and OKRs, to documents and spreadsheets, lives in one tab all in Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable workflow principle: consolidate key artifacts (OKRs, trackers, docs, spreadsheets) into a single source of truth to reduce coordination overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Coda's collaborative all in one workspace, you get the flexibility of docs, the structure of spreadsheets, the power of applications, and the intelligence of AI, all in one easy to organize tab.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable “bundle” model for tooling—combine docs + spreadsheets + apps + AI in one place to support end-to-end execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: More than 50,000 teams trust Coda to keep them more aligned and focused.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete adoption data point that signals scale and social proof for the workflow approach being described.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Curiosity is the most common way to describe. At every stage of life, curiosity is something to cultivate.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A succinct, transferable development principle: prioritize cultivating curiosity as a lifelong skill.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring older talent: generalists and mutual mentorship
quotes.text: I think we're moving into, there's a book that David Epstein wrote called Range, and the whole premise of range is that we are moving out of the era of the specialists and into the era of the generalists. I think AI is just accelerating this.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A clear hiring/strategy framework: as AI speeds up execution, generalists who think broadly become more valuable than narrow specialists.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring older talent: generalists and mutual mentorship
quotes.text: I would also say, are they a generalist when they're a problem solver? I actually think that's going to be an increasingly important part of how effective companies think broadly.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A practical interview lens: evaluate candidates on generalist problem-solving ability, not just role-specific experience.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring older talent: generalists and mutual mentorship
quotes.text: I think also, this idea of how do you create intergenerational collaboration in the form of mutual mentorships? One of the things I loved at Airbnb, there were a few people I did this with, where I had something to teach them and they had something to teach me.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A repeatable org design tactic: set up mutual mentorship so knowledge flows both ways across generations.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring older talent: generalists and mutual mentorship
quotes.text: Give me, in a paragraph, a thorny problem you faced. What was the problem, and what skills you used to actually accomplish it, and what was the result of that?
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A concrete resume/interview format that emphasizes problem-solving narrative and measurable outcomes over job titles and bullet points.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring older talent: generalists and mutual mentorship
quotes.text: If I was just the older elder, dispensing wisdom, people would've gotten bored very quickly.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A counterintuitive point about older talent: impact comes from curiosity and engagement, not just “experience” or authority.

quotes.topic_title: Founding Joie de Vivre and midlife turning point
quotes.text: I was bored silly. I wanted to do something more creative.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic for career/product fit: boredom can be a signal to seek more creative, intrinsically motivating work.

quotes.topic_title: Founding Joie de Vivre and midlife turning point
quotes.text: What San Francisco really needs is a rock and roll hotel.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A crisp “jobs-to-be-done” style articulation of an unmet market need that can anchor a differentiated strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Founding Joie de Vivre and midlife turning point
quotes.text: I loved it till I hated it.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A memorable way to describe founder/leader burnout and the importance of reassessing motivation as circumstances change.

quotes.topic_title: Founding Joie de Vivre and midlife turning point
quotes.text: From that point forward, I realized every day is a gift and a bonus, and I decided to sell my company at the bottom of the great recession.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A counterintuitive decision-making moment—prioritizing life/time and long-term optionality over waiting for “better” market timing.

quotes.topic_title: Founding Joie de Vivre and midlife turning point
quotes.text: That's really how I created this space in my life to be able to join Airbnb.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Highlights the practical strategy of creating “space” (capacity/optionality) to enable the next career or product chapter.

quotes.topic_title: Near-death experience and its life message
quotes.text: I went flatlined from the allergic reaction to the antibiotic. I saw, it happened nine times over 90 minutes, I kept dying, kept flatlining, yeah.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A striking, specific data point that underscores how extreme the experience was and why it catalyzed change.

quotes.topic_title: Near-death experience and its life message
quotes.text: One slipper said slow, the other slipper said down.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A memorable, portable cue practitioners can turn into a concrete reminder system to counteract momentum and overwork.

quotes.topic_title: Near-death experience and its life message
quotes.text: They kept telling me, "If you slow down, you will see beauty and you will see awe."
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A simple mental model: slowing down is not just rest—it changes what you perceive and prioritize.

quotes.topic_title: Near-death experience and its life message
quotes.text: Within two years, I'd sold it, and I had the chance to move on.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A concrete example of how a reframed priority set can rapidly translate into major strategic life decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Culture as an operating system for companies
quotes.text: Culture is what happens around here when the boss is not around.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A crisp, operational definition of culture that makes it measurable through behavior and decisions in the absence of oversight.

quotes.topic_title: Culture as an operating system for companies
quotes.text: The more distributed a company, the more culture is important.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Highlights why remote/distributed orgs must invest more intentionally in culture because informal alignment mechanisms are weaker.

quotes.topic_title: Culture as an operating system for companies
quotes.text: At the end of the day, the reason the culture is important is because it actually helps, it helps guide people in terms of making decisions, but it's also a magnet for the right kind of people.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Connects culture to two concrete operating outcomes: decentralized decision-making and hiring/retention pull.

quotes.topic_title: Culture as an operating system for companies
quotes.text: I like to say culture add, because culture fit to me can actually be quite negative toward somebody who is the aberration.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: Reframes “culture fit” into a more inclusive, performance-oriented hiring lens that values diversity as additive.

quotes.topic_title: Culture as an operating system for companies
quotes.text: We saw it at Airbnb all over and over again. In fact, Airbnb saw it, I think when with Amazon people. Apple people have resonated pretty well at Airbnb, Amazon people, less so.
quotes.speaker: Chip Conley
quotes.context: A concrete example of how culture mismatch can show up even among high performers from top companies, reinforcing the need to evaluate culture explicitly.
